    Chase Bank Review

    Written by Kit Pulliam edited by Sophia Acevedoreviewed by Evelyn He
    Affiliate links for the products on this page are from partners that compensate us and terms apply to offers listed (see our advertiser disclosure with our list of partners for more details). However, our opinions are our own. See how we rate banking products to write unbiased product reviews.

    This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now. Have an account? .

    Business Insider's personal finance team compared Chase to the best banks and found it to be an industry leader in some areas, such as checking accounts for nationwide banks, mortgages, and credit cards, and standard in other areas, such as traditional savings accounts.

    You may prefer Chase to other banks if you like a nationwide branch and ATM network. It's listed in our guides for best credit cards. Other financial institutions pay higher interest rates on savings accounts, though.

    Chase Overview

    Chase is a brick-and-mortar bank with more than 4,700 branches and more than 15,000 free ATMs. Bank accounts can be opened online from anywhere in the continental U.S.

    Chase banking offers 24/7 customer service over the phone or online. For specific brick-and-mortar locations, customer support may vary depending on where you live. Generally, branches have customer support available on weekdays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. for that time zone.

    Its mobile banking app is rated 4.8 out of 5 stars in the Apple store, and 4.4 out of 5 stars in the Google Play Store.

    Chase is FDIC-insured. Up to $250,000 per depositor, per category is secure in an individual bank account.

    Chase Bank Fees and Charges

    Chase Bank Monthly Maintenance Fees

    Depending on which Chase Bank services you're interested in, you might end up with monthly service fees. For example, Chase Savings℠ and Chase Premier Savings℠ Account come with a monthly service fee, and several of the bank's checking accounts come with monthly service fees as well.

    Chase bank accounts generally come with ways to waive those fees, but if you can't meet those requirements, you might be more interested in banks that avoid bank fees instead.

    Chase Bank Overdraft Fees

    Chase is not a bank that avoids overdraft fees entirely; it charges a $34 overdraft fee if you make a purchase your account can't cover. However, Chase does let you hook up your savings account in case of overdrafts, letting you automatically pull funds from your savings account to cover purchases your checking account doesn't have money for. You won't have to pay a fee if Chase ends up pulling funds from your savings account.

    Chase Bank ATM Fees

    No matter what, you won't have to pay ATM fees if you go to a Chase ATM. There are 15,000 Chase ATMS across the U.S., so there's a good chance you'll be able to find an in-network ATM near you. If you want to avoid ATM fees at out-of-network ATMs, even those outside of the U.S., Chase Sapphire℠ Banking is your best bet. Not only does the account not come with any ATM fees no matter where you are in the world, but you'll also be refunded any ATM fees that out-of-network ATM providers might charge you.

    Chase Bank Pros and Cons

    Chase Bank Pros

    • Access to 4,700 branches and 15,000 free ATMs throughout the U.S.
    • Variety of bank accounts, including special options for kids
    • Checking account bonuses featured in our best bank account bonuses guide
    • Variety of rewards credit cards
    • Chase DreaMaker mortgage helps lower-income borrowers

    Chase Bank Cons

    • Low interest rates on savings accounts
    • No money market account
    • Does not offer auto refinancing
    • Does not offer USDA loans, home equity loans, reverse mortgages, or construction loans

    Chase banking options include a traditional savings account and a premium savings account. The main downside to both accounts is that they pay low savings rates.

    According to the FDIC, the average savings account in the U.S. has an interest rate of 0.42% APY. If you are looking to earn a more competitive interest rate, read through our best high-yield savings account guide.

    Chase has CD options from one month to 10 years, which is a greater variety than most banks offer.

    The standard interest rate is the same as the savings account's rate, but you'll earn a better "relationship rate" if you also have a Chase checking account. Online banks and credit unions pay higher interest rates overall, though.

    Chase offers investing and wealth management services through J.P. Morgan, another part of the company. You'll be able to trade stocks, ETFs, options, and mutual funds. Depending on what brokerage account you choose, you can handle trading yourself or get help from financial advisors.

    Is Chase Trustworthy?

    We use ratings from the Better Business Bureau to see how banks respond to customer issues. The BBB gives Chase an A- rating because it hasn't responded to a few complaints from customers.

    The bank does have a recent public controversy, though.

    In 2023, it was required to pay $75 million in a settlement with the U.S. Virgin Islands that accused the financial institution of failing to report suspicious activity regarding Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking operation.

    Chase Bank Alternatives

    Chase Bank vs. Bank of America

    You might prefer Bank of America for a savings account because the Bank of America Advantage Savings Account, with an interest rate of 0.01% to 0.04% APY, automatically waives its monthly fee for the first six months. Opening this account also makes you eligible to earn cash-back rewards when you use your debit card with select retailers.

    Chase may be better if you're searching for the right checking account, though. There are several Chase checking accounts, so you're likely to find one that fits your needs.

    Bank of America Review

    Chase Bank vs. Wells Fargo

    The Wells Fargo Way2Save® Savings Account, which offers an interest rate of 0.01% APY, is appealing because it has tools to help you save more. For example, the Save As You Go® feature transfers $1 from checking to savings each time you swipe your debit card.

    Chase offers many more checking account options than Wells Fargo, so you might find the best fit with Chase. As far as CDs go, it depends on which CD term length you're looking for. Wells Fargo CD rates are decent, but the bank only offers terms up to one year. Meanwhile, Chase has CD terms as high as 10 years.

    Wells Fargo Review

    Why You Should Trust Us: How We Reviewed Chase Bank

    At Business Insider, we use our bank account rating methodology guidelines to rate all of our banking products.

    We rate products on a scale from one to five stars. For bank accounts, we review different features for distinct types of bank accounts. For example, we'll look at early withdrawal penalties and CD variety specifically for CDs. Meanwhile, for checking accounts, we'll factor in the ATM network size and fees, as well as its overdraft protection options.

    When we're calculating the total star rating of a bank account, we use a weighted average. Each feature will be scored from 0 to 5, and some features, such as interest rates and fees, will have a weight percentage.

    Chase Bank FAQs

    What services does Chase offer?

    Chase offers many different personal and business banking services, such as savings accounts, checking accounts, credit cards, and mortgages. It also offers investing services and wealth management through the J.P. Morgan side of the company.

    What are the fees associated with Chase bank accounts?

    Depending on the account you're interested in, you might end up paying monthly service fees, overdraft fees, minimum opening deposits, or ATM fees. Some of these fees can be waived if you meet the requirements, though.

    How can I contact Chase Bank customer service?

    You can contact Chase Bank customer service by calling, sending an email, sending physical mail, or going into a physical branch and asking for help.

    Is Chase Bank a good bank?

    Yes, Chase Bank is a good bank for many products, such as credit cards, checking accounts, and mortgages.

    Is Chase Bank FDIC-insured?

    Yes, Chase Bank is FDIC-insured. Your bank accounts are safe up to $250,000 per depositor.
